There is no new major legislation that would even be eligible to filibuster. BCRA uses reconciliation and only requires 51 votes. Tax reform will be pursued through reconciliation (hence why they haven't started it, only one reconciliation bill is allowed at a time) and will only require 51 votes. The budget could be filibustered, but no one is really itching for a shutdown (save for WH), and besides, we'll be on a CR through Dec 8 at the earliest. Debt ceiling could be filibustered, but it has bipartisan support and can likely get over the 60 vote bar.

The inability of the WH and Congress to pass these pieces is more a reflection of the internecine warfare being waged within the GOP than anything the Dems are doing. If anything, this discord should reemphasize to McConnell the GOP need for a legislative filibuster, as the Dems traditionally pass larger entitlement-based programs that would be nearly impossible to undo if the Dems took control of the WH and both chambers.

This is entirely up to Mitch McConnell. This is a matter of changing Senate rules and only the majority leader has the authority to bring that issue to the floor. He will not hesitate to change the rules, but to do it he needs 51 Republican votes. To get those, he needs a big enough issue to make it all worthwhile since eliminating the filibuster could backfire. There is no such issue in the pipeline. Healthcare isn't it: if anything ever comes out of the House, it will be some unlovable mutant that will likely be suffocated in conference so that no Senator has to vote on it publicly. The budget might be it, but that has to start in the House. Even then, McConnell has the option of doing some reconciliation magic to get it through on 51 votes. Wait on this one to see where we are in September. Tax reform might be it, but that, too, has to start in the House and Paul Ryan seems to be having trouble passing the salt, as they say, let alone something as complex as a tax reform package. Were I McConnell, I'd wait for the 2018 mid-terms. The Ds have 25 seats up of which 13 are in play to some degree. The Rs have 9 seats up of which 2 are in play. There's a better than even chance that the Rs could have a filibuster-proof 60 votes in the 116th. Why risk unforeseeable backlash for changing the rules if you can get what you want under the current rules by just holding tight for 18 months? Yes, it's a long game, but McConnell is very good at the long game.
